.footer .uk-container {
	max-width: 1300px;
}


.footer p {
	color:white !important;
}
.footer a {
	text-decoration: underline;
}
.wpcf7-form {
	text-align: left;
	padding: 20px 0;
}


.wpcf7-text, .wpcf7-textarea, .wpcf7-submit {
	padding: 15px;
	border: 1px solid #E8E8E8;
	width: 90%;
}

.wpcf7-submit {
	background-color: #f7f7f7;
	border: 2px solid #e75d1f;
	color: #e75d1f;
	text-transform: uppercase;
	padding: 15px;
	transition: 0.2s ease;
	width: 40%;
	float: center;
	
}

.wpcf7-submit:hover {
	background-color: #e75d1f;
	color: #fff;
	transition: 0.2s ease;
	cursor: pointer;
}
.my-map { max-height: 650px;}

#map {height:650px; width:100%; margin:0; padding:0;}

.legenda {display:none;}

			//shadowAnchor: [4, 62],  // the same for the shadow
			popupAnchor:  [0, -15] // point from which the popup should open relative to the iconAnchor
		});
*/
		
		var cervena = L.icon({
			iconUrl: 'https://glodep.eu/cervena.png',
			//shadowUrl: 'leaf-shadow.png',

			iconSize:     [30, 30], // size of the icon
			//shadowSize:   [50, 64], // size of the shadow
			iconAnchor:   [15, 15], // point of the icon which will correspond to marker's location
			//shadowAnchor: [4, 62],  // the same for the shadow
			popupAnchor:  [0, -15] // point from which the popup should open relative to the iconAnchor
		});

		/*
		var modra = L.icon({
			iconUrl: 'https://glodep.eu/modra.png',
			//shadowUrl: 'leaf-shadow.png',

			iconSize:     [30, 30], // size of the icon
			//shadowSize:   [50, 64], // size of the shadow
			iconAnchor:   [15, 15], // point of the icon which will correspond to marker's location
			//shadowAnchor: [4, 62],  // the same for the shadow
			popupAnchor:  [0, -15] // point from which the popup should open relative to the iconAnchor
		});
		*/
		
		function onEachFeature(feature, layer) {
		var popupContent = "<b>" + feature.properties.nazev + "</b><br />";
				 
				 

		if (feature.properties && feature.properties.popupContent) {
			popupContent += feature.properties.popupContent;
		}

		layer.bindPopup(popupContent);
		}



		var map = L.map('map').addLayer(CartoDB_Voyager);

		map.scrollWheelZoom.disable();	
		//var map = new L.Map('map', {zoom: 5, maxZoom: 20, center: new L.latLng([37.8, -96]) });
		//map.addLayer(CartoDB_Voyager);

			style: function (feature) {

			onEachFeature:onEachFeature  
		});

		map.addLayer(geoJsonLayer3);
    map.addLayer(geoJsonLayer1);

		map.setView([20, 70], 2);

		var mapycz2 = new L.tileLayer('http://m{s}.mapserver.mapy.cz/ophoto-m/{z}-{x}-{y}',{ident:'mapycz',attribution:'©Seznam.cz a.s., | ©OpenStreetMap <a href="http://mapy.cz"><img decoding="async" class="print" target="_blank" src="//api.mapy.cz/img/api/logo.png" style="cursor: pointer; position:relative;top: 5px;"></a>',maxZoom:21,subdomains:"1234"});

*/

		maxZoom: 19
		});

			//shadowAnchor: [4, 62],  // the same for the shadow
			popupAnchor:  [0, -15] // point from which the popup should open relative to the iconAnchor
		});
*/
		
		var cervena = L.icon({
			iconUrl: 'https://glodep.eu/cervena.png',
			//shadowUrl: 'leaf-shadow.png',

			iconSize:     [30, 30], // size of the icon
			//shadowSize:   [50, 64], // size of the shadow
			iconAnchor:   [15, 15], // point of the icon which will correspond to marker's location
			//shadowAnchor: [4, 62],  // the same for the shadow
			popupAnchor:  [0, -15] // point from which the popup should open relative to the iconAnchor
		});

		/*
		var modra = L.icon({
			iconUrl: 'https://glodep.eu/modra.png',
			//shadowUrl: 'leaf-shadow.png',

			iconSize:     [30, 30], // size of the icon
			//shadowSize:   [50, 64], // size of the shadow
			iconAnchor:   [15, 15], // point of the icon which will correspond to marker's location
			//shadowAnchor: [4, 62],  // the same for the shadow
			popupAnchor:  [0, -15] // point from which the popup should open relative to the iconAnchor
		});
		*/
		
		function onEachFeature(feature, layer) {
		var popupContent = "<b>" + feature.properties.nazev + "</b><br />";
				 
				 

		if (feature.properties && feature.properties.popupContent) {
			popupContent += feature.properties.popupContent;
		}

		layer.bindPopup(popupContent);
		}



		var map = L.map('map').addLayer(CartoDB_Voyager);

		map.scrollWheelZoom.disable();	
		//var map = new L.Map('map', {zoom: 5, maxZoom: 20, center: new L.latLng([37.8, -96]) });
		//map.addLayer(CartoDB_Voyager);

			onEachFeature:onEachFeature  
		});
		
		var geoJsonLayer3 = L.geoJson(geoJsonData3, {
			style: function (feature) {
			return { weight: 1,  color: "darkgrey", fillOpacity: 0.5 };

    /*

		map.addLayer(geoJsonLayer3);
    map.addLayer(geoJsonLayer1);
    */
		map.addLayer(geoJsonLayer4);
    
		map.setView([20, 70], 2);
		//map.fitBounds(geoJsonLayer1.getBounds());
				
		var baseMaps = {
			"Letecká - mapy.cz": mapycz2,

		};

			//"markers": markers
		};

		//L.control.layers(baseMaps, overlayMaps,{collapsed:false}).addTo(map);

.footer .uk-container {
	max-width: 1300px;
}


.footer p {
	color:white !important;
}
.footer a {
	text-decoration: underline;
}
.wpcf7-form {
	text-align: left;
	padding: 20px 0;
}


.wpcf7-text, .wpcf7-textarea, .wpcf7-submit {
	padding: 15px;
	border: 1px solid #E8E8E8;
	width: 90%;
}

.wpcf7-submit {
	background-color: #f7f7f7;
	border: 2px solid #e75d1f;
	color: #e75d1f;
	text-transform: uppercase;
	padding: 15px;
	transition: 0.2s ease;
	width: 40%;
	float: center;
	
}

.wpcf7-submit:hover {
	background-color: #e75d1f;
	color: #fff;
	transition: 0.2s ease;
	cursor: pointer;
}

#map {height:650px; width:100%; margin:0; padding:0;}

*/

			//shadowAnchor: [4, 62],  // the same for the shadow
			popupAnchor:  [0, -15] // point from which the popup should open relative to the iconAnchor
		});
*/
		
		var cervena = L.icon({
			iconUrl: 'https://glodep.eu/cervena.png',
			//shadowUrl: 'leaf-shadow.png',

			iconSize:     [30, 30], // size of the icon
			//shadowSize:   [50, 64], // size of the shadow
			iconAnchor:   [15, 15], // point of the icon which will correspond to marker's location
			//shadowAnchor: [4, 62],  // the same for the shadow
			popupAnchor:  [0, -15] // point from which the popup should open relative to the iconAnchor
		});

		/*
		var modra = L.icon({
			iconUrl: 'https://glodep.eu/modra.png',
			//shadowUrl: 'leaf-shadow.png',

			iconSize:     [30, 30], // size of the icon
			//shadowSize:   [50, 64], // size of the shadow
			iconAnchor:   [15, 15], // point of the icon which will correspond to marker's location
			//shadowAnchor: [4, 62],  // the same for the shadow
			popupAnchor:  [0, -15] // point from which the popup should open relative to the iconAnchor
		});
		*/
		
		function onEachFeature(feature, layer) {
		var popupContent = "<b>" + feature.properties.nazev + "</b><br />";
				 
				 

		if (feature.properties && feature.properties.popupContent) {
			popupContent += feature.properties.popupContent;
		}

		layer.bindPopup(popupContent);
		}



		var map = L.map('map').addLayer(CartoDB_Voyager);

		map.scrollWheelZoom.disable();	
		//var map = new L.Map('map', {zoom: 5, maxZoom: 20, center: new L.latLng([37.8, -96]) });
		//map.addLayer(CartoDB_Voyager);

			onEachFeature:onEachFeature  
		});
		
		var geoJsonLayer3 = L.geoJson(geoJsonData3, {
			style: function (feature) {

			onEachFeature:onEachFeature  
		});	
    
		//markers.addLayer(geoJsonLayer);

    map.addLayer(geoJsonLayer1);

.footer .uk-container {
	max-width: 1300px;
}


.footer p {
	color:white !important;
}
.footer a {
	text-decoration: underline;
}
.wpcf7-form {
	text-align: left;
	padding: 20px 0;
}


.wpcf7-text, .wpcf7-textarea, .wpcf7-submit {
	padding: 15px;
	border: 1px solid #E8E8E8;
	width: 90%;
}

.wpcf7-submit {
	background-color: #f7f7f7;
	border: 2px solid #e75d1f;
	color: #e75d1f;
	text-transform: uppercase;
	padding: 15px;
	transition: 0.2s ease;
	width: 40%;
	float: center;
	
}

.wpcf7-submit:hover {
	background-color: #e75d1f;
	color: #fff;
	transition: 0.2s ease;
	cursor: pointer;
}

#map {height:650px; width:100%; margin:0; padding:0;}

   <main class="tm-main uk-section uk-section-default" id="tm-main" uk-height-viewport="expand: true">
    <div class="uk-container">
     <article class="uk-article post-350 page type-page status-publish hentry" id="post-350" typeof="Article" vocab="https://schema.org/">
      <meta content="About" property="name"/>
      <meta content="Lenka Volenikova" property="author" typeof="Person"/>
      <meta content="2024-10-23T07:20:13+00:00" property="dateModified"/>
      <meta class="uk-margin-remove-adjacent" content="2019-10-19T09:09:21+00:00" property="datePublished"/>
      <h1 class="uk-article-title">
       About
      </h1>
      <div class="uk-margin-medium" property="text">
       <p>
        <span style="font-weight: 400;">
         GLODEP – GLOBAL DEVELOPMENT POLICY – is a two-year joint master program in development studies with an economic grounding and multidisciplinary perspective. GLODEP has a fixed structure: first semester at
        </span>
        <a href="http://www.upol.cz/en/">
         <span style="font-weight: 400;">
          Palacky University
         </span>
        </a>
        <span style="font-weight: 400;">
         Olomouc
        </span>
        <span style="font-weight: 400;">
         (Olomouc, Czech Republic), second semester at the
        </span>
        <a href="https://www.uni-goettingen.de/en/the+university/50217.html">
         <span style="font-weight: 400;">
          University of Göttingen
         </span>
        </a>
        <span style="font-weight: 400;">
         (Göttingen, Germany), and a third semester at the
        </span>
        <a href="http://www.clermont-universite.fr/">
         <span style="font-weight: 400;">
          University Clermont Auvergne
         </span>
        </a>
        <span style="font-weight: 400;">
         (Clermont-Ferrand, France). The fourth semester is dedicated to an internship or research stay, preferably with associated partners of the Consortium (see
        </span>
        <a href="https://glodep.eu/new/consortium/academic-associates/">
         <span style="font-weight: 400;">
          Academic Associates
         </span>
        </a>
        <span style="font-weight: 400;">
         and
        </span>
        <a href="https://glodep.eu/new/consortium/non-academic-associates/">
         <span style="font-weight: 400;">
          Non-Academic Associates
         </span>
        </a>
        <span style="font-weight: 400;">
         ); and to
        </span>
        <a href="https://glodep.eu/master/examination-and-thesis/">
         <span style="font-weight: 400;">
          thesis writing.
         </span>
        </a>
       </p>
       <p>
        <span style="font-weight: 400;">
         The aim of GLODEP is to prepare professionals in the field of international development. GLODEP (Global Development Policy) provides students with comprehensive knowledge and skills to analyze development issues and to design and promote development policies at national, regional, and international levels. GLODEP links the areas of development studies and development economics, offering insights from economics and other fields, such as geography, environmental studies, and political science.
        </span>
       </p>
       <p>
        <span style="font-weight: 400;">
         The program provides the students with an opportunity to obtain:
        </span>
       </p>
       <ul>
        <li aria-level="1" style="font-weight: 400;">
         <span style="font-weight: 400;">
          multi-disciplinary knowledge of development issues grounded in development studies and development economics;
         </span>
        </li>
        <li aria-level="1" style="font-weight: 400;">
         <span style="font-weight: 400;">
          ability to analyze development problems and to design and promote development policies and projects for the specific context of a developing area or a sector;
         </span>
        </li>
        <li aria-level="1" style="font-weight: 400;">
         <span style="font-weight: 400;">
          ability to work in an international environment and in multi- and inter-disciplinary teams, and communicate to a non-expert audience.
         </span>
        </li>
       </ul>
       <h3>
        <b>
         Career
        </b>
       </h3>
       <p>
        <span style="font-weight: 400;">
         GLODEP (Global Development Policy) enables the graduates to work in higher-level positions (for example as government policy officers and project managers) in international organizations (e.g. UN agencies, World Trade Organization, development banks), non-governmental organizations (e.g. Oxfam and World Vision) and in governments (e.g. national development agencies and various ministries), as well as in businesses; with a focus on sustainable economic and human development. Reflecting the character of the program, the graduates will be suited to work in teams of people with diverse professional experience and from a range of disciplinary backgrounds.
        </span>
       </p>
       <p>
        <span style="font-weight: 400;">
         Our alumni professional path can be followed at alumni and
         <a href="https://www.linkedin.com/school/glodep/?viewAsMember=true">
          LinkedIN.
         </a>
        </span>
       </p>
       <div class="updated">
        Updated: 23/10/2024
       </div>
      </div>
     </article>
    </div>

}

	font-size: 16px;
}

	margin: 5px 0;

	font-size: 15px;
}

	margin-top: 5px;

.footer .uk-container {
	max-width: 1300px;
}


.footer p {
	color:white !important;
}
.footer a {
	text-decoration: underline;
}
.wpcf7-form {
	text-align: left;
	padding: 20px 0;
}


.wpcf7-text, .wpcf7-textarea, .wpcf7-submit {
	padding: 15px;
	border: 1px solid #E8E8E8;
	width: 90%;
}

.wpcf7-submit {
	background-color: #f7f7f7;
	border: 2px solid #e75d1f;
	color: #e75d1f;
	text-transform: uppercase;
	padding: 15px;
	transition: 0.2s ease;
	width: 40%;
	float: center;
	
}

.wpcf7-submit:hover {
	background-color: #e75d1f;
	color: #fff;
	transition: 0.2s ease;
	cursor: pointer;
}
.my-map { max-height: 650px;}

#map {height:650px; width:100%; margin:0; padding:0;}

.legenda {display:none;}

#map, .legenda {display:none;}

	font-size:18px; background: #ff9500;}

.tm-toolbar a {color:white; text-decoration: underline;}

.tm-toolbar a:hover {color:rgba(255,255,255,0.7); text-decoration: none;}

.tabulka {
    border: 1px solid lightgrey;
}
.tabulka td:not(:last-child) {
    vertical-align: middle !important;
    border-right: 1px solid lightgrey;
}
.tabulka thead {
    background-color: #E75D1F;
}

.tabulka thead h4 {
    color: #fff; text-align:center; padding:0px 20px;
}

        <h2 class="uk-margin-top uk-margin-remove-bottom uk-article-title" property="headline">

          NEW CALL FOR APPLICATIONS IS OPEN
         </a>
        </h2>
        <p class="uk-margin-top uk-margin-remove-bottom uk-article-meta">
         Written on

         </time>
         .                Posted in
         <a href="https://glodep.eu/category/news/" rel="category tag">
          News
         </a>
         .
        </p>
        <div class="uk-margin-medium-top" property="text">
         The call for the 2025-2027 intake applications is open by 31st January 2025 for the potential unguaranteed EMJM scholarship applicants and by 30th April 2025 for self-paid applicants. More info.
The Consortium applies for support from EACEA in 2025. Therefore, the scholarship is only potential and unguaranteed as the Consortium will receive the results only in summer 2025. The selected candidates will be promptly informed. Now, at the application stage, the Consortium cannot guarantee this scholarship.

         </a>

        </p>
        <div class="uk-margin-medium-top" property="text">
         The call for the 2025–2027 intake applications is open from November 2024 until the 31st of January 2025 (23:59 CET) for the potential unguaranteed EMJM scholarship applicants and by 30th April 2025 (23:59 CET) for self-paid applicants.        <article class="uk-article post-1384 post type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-news" id="post-1384" typeof="Article" vocab="https://schema.org/">
        <meta content="PERSPECTIVE ON DEVELOPMENT" property="name"/>
        <meta content="Lenka Volenikova" property="author" typeof="Person"/>
        <meta content="2024-10-23T08:11:14+00:00" property="dateModified"/>
        <meta class="uk-margin-remove-adjacent" content="2024-10-23T08:11:14+00:00" property="datePublished"/>
        <h2 class="uk-margin-top uk-margin-remove-bottom uk-article-title" property="headline">
         <a class="uk-link-reset" href="https://glodep.eu/perspective-on-development/">
          PERSPECTIVE ON DEVELOPMENT
         </a>
        </h2>
        <p class="uk-margin-top uk-margin-remove-bottom uk-article-meta">
         Written on
         <time datetime="2024-10-23T08:11:14+00:00">
          23. 10. 2024
         </time>
         .                Posted in
         <a href="https://glodep.eu/category/news/" rel="category tag">
          News
         </a>
         .
        </p>
        <div class="uk-margin-medium-top" property="text">
         Today was a truly special day for my students in the #Erasmus Mundus Joint Master Degree Glodep – Global Development Policy! 


We had the chance to participate in a seminar on “Perspectives on Development”, featuring insightful contributions from:


Prof. Osw from Salahaddin University (Iraq) 
Prof. Abdellatif from Fayoum University (Egypt) 
Prof. Msosa from the University of Malawi (Malawi) 


We were also honored by the presence of Prof. Gian Battista Prigi, the Rector’s Delegate for International Cooperation at the University of Pavia, who added depth to our discussions on global cooperation and development.


It was an incredible opportunity to dive into the many dimensions of development and engage in meaningful dialogue about the global challenges we face. I’m proud of my students for making the most of this learning experience!



Università degli studi di Pavia University of Pavia – Centre for International Cooperation and Development
        </div>
        <p class="uk-margin-medium">
         <a class="uk-button uk-button-primary" href="https://glodep.eu/perspective-on-development/">
          Continue reading
         </a>
        </p>
       </article>
      </div>

	max-width: 1400px;

}

	padding: 0; 
}

.my-contact {
	padding: 20px;
}

.uk-navbar-container .uk-container {
	max-width: 1300px
}

.widgetkit_newsfeed .wk-h4 {
	margin: 0;
	font-size: 16px;
}

.widgetkit_newsfeed .wk-article-meta {
	margin: 5px 0;
	color: #bbb;
	font-size: 15px;
}

.widgetkit_newsfeed .wk-margin {
	margin: 0;
}

.widgetkit_newsfeed p {
	margin-top: 5px;
}

	padding: 15px 25px;
}

.footer .uk-container {
	max-width: 1300px;
}


.footer p {
	color:white !important;
}
.footer a {
	text-decoration: underline;
}
.wpcf7-form {
	text-align: left;
	padding: 20px 0;
}


.wpcf7-text, .wpcf7-textarea, .wpcf7-submit {
	padding: 15px;
	border: 1px solid #E8E8E8;
	width: 90%;
}

.wpcf7-submit {
	background-color: #f7f7f7;
	border: 2px solid #e75d1f;
	color: #e75d1f;
	text-transform: uppercase;
	padding: 15px;
	transition: 0.2s ease;
	width: 40%;
	float: center;
	
}

.wpcf7-submit:hover {
	background-color: #e75d1f;
	color: #fff;
	transition: 0.2s ease;
	cursor: pointer;
}
.my-map { max-height: 650px;}

#map {height:650px; width:100%; margin:0; padding:0;}

.legenda {display:none;}

.legenda {bottom: 200px;

*/

#map, .legenda {display:none;}
}

	font-size:18px; background: #ff9500;}

.tm-toolbar a {color:white; text-decoration: underline;}

.tm-toolbar a:hover {color:rgba(255,255,255,0.7); text-decoration: none;}

.tabulka {
    border: 1px solid lightgrey;
}
.tabulka td:not(:last-child) {
    vertical-align: middle !important;
    border-right: 1px solid lightgrey;
}
.tabulka thead {
    background-color: #E75D1F;
}

.tabulka thead h4 {
    color: #fff; text-align:center; padding:0px 20px;
}

   <main class="tm-main uk-section uk-section-default" id="tm-main" uk-height-viewport="expand: true">
    <div class="uk-container">
     <article class="uk-article post-352 page type-page status-publish hentry" id="post-352" typeof="Article" vocab="https://schema.org/">
      <meta content="Curriculum" property="name"/>
      <meta content="Lenka Volenikova" property="author" typeof="Person"/>
      <meta content="2024-12-02T11:52:18+00:00" property="dateModified"/>
      <meta class="uk-margin-remove-adjacent" content="2019-10-19T09:09:56+00:00" property="datePublished"/>
      <h1 class="uk-article-title">
       Curriculum
      </h1>
      <div class="uk-margin-medium" property="text">
       <p>
        <span style="font-weight: 400;">
         The program consists of four semesters, with mobility between universities in the first three semesters and a research stay or internship in the fourth. To ensure the internal coherency of the program, the curriculum is fixed for the first three semesters. The first semester at Palacky University Olomouc (Czech Republic) provides a balanced overview of development issues from various disciplinary perspectives. The second semester at the University of Göttingen (Germany) opens relevant debates in development policy and practice, the third semester at the University Clermont Auvergne (France) continues to build a solid quantitative and economic background and prepares students for thesis writing. In the fourth semester, the students conduct their research or internship and write their thesis.
        </span>
       </p>
       <p>
        <span style="font-weight: 400;">
         Each university offers orientation week/days and also language courses (Czech, German, French) to help the students to integrate into daily life in the respective countries. Career days are an integral part of the curriculum in each semester. Students receive advice on their professional portfolio and have an opportunity to meet potential employers.
        </span>
       </p>
       <h4>
        1
        <sup>
         st
        </sup>
        semester, Palacký University (Olomouc, Czech Republic): September – January in the 1
        <sup>
         st
        </sup>
        academic year
       </h4>
       <p>
        <a href="https://studydevelopment.cz/">
         Department of Development and Environmental Studies, Faculty of Science, Palacký University Olomouc
        </a>
       </p>
       <div class="wk-accordion wk-text-left" data-wk-accordion="{collapse: false,showfirst: false}">
        <h3 class="wk-accordion-title">
         FORESIGHT
        </h3>
        <div class="wk-accordion-content">
         <div class="wk-margin">
          <p>
           According to Paul Valéry „the future is not what it used to be“. We can study the past, and we can understand it to a large extent and interpret it in different ways, but we cannot change it. On the contrary, we can never certainly predict or know the future, but through our thoughts, words, and actions, we can influence it to a certain extent. The discipline dealing with the study of possible futures is called foresight and its aim is not to predict the future, but to think about it, debate on it, and partially influence it in a desirable way. It is open to alternative futures; the future can evolve in different directions. Foresight is also participatory; it does not concern a narrow circle of experts but involves a number of diverse actors. And it is multidisciplinary; a problem cannot be properly understood if it is greatly reduced in order to fit into boxes of individual scientific disciplines. During the introductory course two methods of foresight will be discussed: the Delphi method and using visions in foresight. And two specific topics are included: world population prospects and challenges of migration.
          </p>
         </div>
        </div>
        <h3 class="wk-accordion-title">
         SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT
        </h3>
        <div class="wk-accordion-content">
         <div class="wk-margin">
          <p>
           According to the UN World Commission on Environment and Development (1987) sustainable development is such that „meets the needs of the present without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their own needs. In its broadest sense, the strategy for sustainable development aims to promote harmony among human beings and between humanity and nature“. During the course the following topics will be tackled and discussed: human values compatible and incompatible with sustainable development; economic aspects of sustainable development; technological aspects of sustainable development; political and institutional aspects of sustainable development, consumption and production patterns; indicators of sustainable development; promoting sustainable development (summits, strategies); sustainable retreat or collapse as alternatives to sustainable development.
          </p>
         </div>
        </div>
        <h3 class="wk-accordion-title">
         GLOBAL DEVELOPMENT
        </h3>
        <div class="wk-accordion-content">
         <div class="wk-margin">
          <p>
           The course is about the measurement, problems, and prospects of development in the globalized world. While the focus of the course is on developing countries, many topics are relevant also for advanced countries. The course takes a broad picture and provides an analytical overview of a dozen development issues, including the geographical dimension and the role of national and international policies. The topics covered in the course typically include the concept and measurement of (sustainable) development; regional aspects of development; poverty and inequality; human resources (population, health and education); and trade and finance (trade and industrialization, microfinance, and development aid). Though development issues are viewed mainly from an economic perspective, the course is taught in a non-technical way (the knowledge of introductory economics is therefore an advantage, but not required).
          </p>
         </div>
        </div>
        <h3 class="wk-accordion-title">
         GLOBAL ENVIRONMENTAL GEOGRAPHY
        </h3>
        <div class="wk-accordion-content">
         <div class="wk-margin">
          <p>
           Covering the following topics: i) life on Earth and human environment during cultural evolution; ii) characteristics of selected contemporary global problems and; iii) problems of global environmental governance, the students learn about the concept of sustainable development and present model of human environment. The second part of the course is focused on interactions between human society and the environment in economically less developed countries through inquiring into the following topics: i) the complexity of (theoretical) relations between poverty, development and the environment; ii) environment and development challenges of drylands iii) environment and development challenges of developing tropics; iv); policies and practices focusing on nature conservation and human development (namely traditional exclusionary conservation, community-based approaches and market-based conservation).
          </p>
         </div>
        </div>
        <h3 class="wk-accordion-title">
         DEVELOPMENT THEORIES AND ANTHROPOLOGY
        </h3>
        <div class="wk-accordion-content">
         <div class="wk-margin">
          <p>
           The course Development Theories and Anthropology critically analyzes various development theories and discourses that evolved over time and influenced the development thinking and practice. In particular, this course examines the historical context, the theoretical assumptions, the key arguments and the policy implications of development theories and processes. It also highlights how theories and processes shape the research agenda and empirical studies in the field of development, how these theories criticize one another, and how their criticism have led to reformulation with the changing situations in the late 20th and the early 21st century. The course covers the reflections on development alternatives, including indigenous worldviews and endogenous development approaches. After the completion of the course, students will be expected to understand different perspectives and theories of development, the importance of history, power and culture in development practices, and to discuss implications of different theories for development policy in practice.
          </p>
         </div>
        </div>
        <h3 class="wk-accordion-title">
         POLITICO-GEOGRAPHICAL PROCESSES IN DEVELOPING WORLD
        </h3>
        <div class="wk-accordion-content">
         <div class="wk-margin">
          <p>
           Grounded in the current theoretical debates, the aim of this course is to provide the orientation and allow for the critical analysis of the selected concepts related to the internal political processes on country level as well as the issues related to the wider international politics and security that have impact on such internal processes and vice versa. It specifically focuses the contemporary debates on modern states formation, political regimes, democracy designs, building of democratic institutions and good governance, transitions and the role of external actors in such processes, etc.
          </p>
         </div>
        </div>
        <h3 class="wk-accordion-title">
         RESEARCH METHODS
        </h3>
        <div class="wk-accordion-content">
         <div class="wk-margin">
          <p>
           The main aim of the course is to introduce the students to qualitative and quantitative aspects of academic research, including the philosophy and theory of science, ethics of research and the indicators of quality. It also intends to create space for the students to understand and command the variety of concrete qualitative research techniques of data collection and analysis and to introduce them to the application of elementary quantitative tools for analysis of development issues. Students are going to be introduced to ATLAS.ti for qualitative research and they are going to use STATA software in order to be able to work with various datasets to analyze key development issues.
          </p>
         </div>
        </div>
        <h3 class="wk-accordion-title">
         DEVELOPMENT GEOGRAPHY
        </h3>
        <div class="wk-accordion-content">
         <div class="wk-margin">
          <p>
           The aim of the course is to provide students with an overview of geographical, socio-economical, political and environmental issues related to development in Africa, Asia, and Latin America. The course analyzes specific development opportunities and challenges in these regions.
          </p>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
       <h4>
        2
        <sup>
         nd
        </sup>
        semester, University of Göttingen (Göttingen, Germany): April – July in the 1
        <sup>
         st
        </sup>
        academic year
       </h4>
       <p>
        <a href="https://uni-goettingen.de/en/about+us/66587.html">
         <span data-olk-copy-source="MessageBody">
          Department of Economics, University of
         </span>
         Göttingen
        </a>
       </p>
       <div class="wk-accordion wk-text-left" data-wk-accordion="{collapse: false,showfirst: false}">
        <h3 class="wk-accordion-title">
         DEVELOPMENT POLICY
        </h3>
        <div class="wk-accordion-content">
         <div class="wk-margin">
          <p>
           This course offers insights into the politico-economic analysis of international development policies. Students will obtain an overview on the state of the art of empirical research on development aid and other international development policies. The course discusses the determinants of aid allocation, up-to-date methods for evaluating aid effectiveness at the macro and micro level, the role of conditionality, and potential reasons for the ineffectiveness of aid projects. It also covers non-state development actors, international development organizations, and so-called new donors such as China and India. Students learn to analyze international development policies with politico-economic theories and empirical methods. More specifically, the course covers the following topics (e. g. bilateral aid giving,  multilateral aid giving, emerging donors and lenders, poverty targeting and political capture of aid within countries, aid effectiveness, side effects of aid, aid and migration, trade policies, debt relief, humanitarian assistance).
          </p>
         </div>
        </div>
        <h3 class="wk-accordion-title">
         DEVELOPMENT ECONOMICS II
        </h3>
        <div class="wk-accordion-content">
         <div class="wk-margin">
          <p>
           This course examines development economics issues from a micro perspective. The focus is on understanding the measurement, causes, and consequences of poverty at the household level. After successful completion, students will understand poverty in developing countries, including its measurement and key determinants. The objective of the course is that students can explain the linkages between poverty, hunger, gender inequality, and fertility; analyze how market failures in markets for land, labor, capital, and insurance can trap households in poverty; derive appropriate policy recommendations to tackle poverty traps; use regression analysis and interpret results to assess determinants of poverty and ways to overcome it.
          </p>
         </div>
        </div>
        <h3 class="wk-accordion-title">
         QUASI EXPERIMENTS IN DEVELOPMENT ECONOMICS
        </h3>
        <div class="wk-accordion-content">
         <div class="wk-margin">
          <p>
           The course deals with common quasi-experimental approaches for measuring causal effects in developing economics. The content focuses on the distinction between correlation and causality and provides students with a statistical toolkit which will allow them to plan and conduct their own independent research. Special attention will be paid to the specific assumptions necessary for each technique to measure causal effects and common threats to identification (such as selection bias). The course will also train students in R, an open-source programming language that is increasingly used for econometric analysis. Students will learn how to use quasi-experimental techniques in a practical manner by solving assignments in R, writing a referee report, and presenting their own quasi-experimental research idea.
          </p>
         </div>
        </div>
        <h3 class="wk-accordion-title">
         TOPICS IN DEVELOPMENT ECONOMICS
        </h3>
        <div class="wk-accordion-content">
         <div class="wk-margin">
          <p>
           The course deals with different aspects of relevant economic topics in the field of development economics on the basis of a current issue.
          </p>
         </div>
        </div>
        <h3 class="wk-accordion-title">
         CURRENT DEBATES IN DEVELOPMENT (winter school in development)
        </h3>
        <div class="wk-accordion-content">
         <div class="wk-margin">
          <p>
           The course aims to lead debates on contemporary issues in international development taught by guest lecturers.
          </p>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
       <h4>
        3
        <sup>
         rd
        </sup>
        semester, University of Clermont Auvergne (Clermont Ferrand, France): September – January in the 2
        <sup>
         nd
        </sup>
        academic year
       </h4>
       <p>
        <a href="https://economie.uca.fr/">
         The School of Economics, University of Clermont Auvergne
        </a>
       </p>
       <div class="wk-accordion wk-text-left" data-wk-accordion="{collapse: false,showfirst: false}">
        <h3 class="wk-accordion-title">
         SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT II
        </h3>
        <div class="wk-accordion-content">
         <div class="wk-margin">
          <p>
           This course provides economic tools and policy recommendations on critical topics of sustainable development, such as water, energy, and food resources. It also deals with the economic theory of exhaustible and renewable resource extraction. This course about Sustainable Development will explore many of the fundamental economic principles related to climate change and the impact of international trade on the environment. This course eventually studies the critical linkages between global health and economic development.
          </p>
         </div>
        </div>
        <h3 class="wk-accordion-title">
         QUANTITATIVE TECHNIQUES
        </h3>
        <div class="wk-accordion-content">
         <div class="wk-margin">
          <p>
           This course provides a broad overview of the econometric tools available to analyze economic policies. It includes micro econometrics, which deepens the models and methods of nonlinear models with limited dependent variables. It also covers randomised control experiments and quasi-experiments. This course also studies the econometric methods used for macroeconomic analysis (time series and panel data analysis). To facilitate these learning objectives, the course consists of applications using real data such as survey data sets and STATA or R.
          </p>
         </div>
        </div>
        <h3 class="wk-accordion-title">
         INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPMENT
        </h3>
        <div class="wk-accordion-content">
         <div class="wk-margin">
          <p>
           This course presents and analyses the full range of tools available to finance economic development through public policies, including domestic and international financing. It provides a broad overview of trade policies and their welfare effects and considers the institutional arrangements for trade policies (e.g., regional trade agreements and the World Trade Organization). The course also deals with the interaction between economic policies, politics, administrative capacity, and civil society. The learning objectives will be met with case studies covering either development projects, countries or regions such as Central Asia. Comparative case studies will be carried out at territorial levels and using a system analysis approach.
          </p>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
       <h4>
        4
        <sup>
         th
        </sup>
        semester: Internship/Research stay – February – June in the 2
        <sup>
         nd
        </sup>
        academic year
       </h4>
       <p>
        <span style="font-weight: 400;">
         The fourth semester is dedicated to an obligatory
        </span>
        <a href="https://glodep.eu/master/internships-research-stay/">
         <span style="font-weight: 400;">
          internship or research stay
         </span>
        </a>
        <span style="font-weight: 400;">
         . The students may spend their research stay at one of the Consortium Universities or at the
        </span>
        <a href="https://glodep.eu/consortium/academic-associates/">
         <span style="font-weight: 400;">
          academic associates
         </span>
        </a>
        <span style="font-weight: 400;">
         . Internship stays may be carried out at
        </span>
        <a href="https://glodep.eu/consortium/non-academic-associates/">
         <span style="font-weight: 400;">
          non-academic associates
         </span>
        </a>
        <span style="font-weight: 400;">
         or relevant organizations outside the Consortium.
        </span>
        <span style="font-weight: 400;">
         During the 4th semester, students also prepare their thesis. The thesis (30 ECTS) should be the outcome of the internship/research stay.
        </span>
       </p>
       <p>
       </p>
       <div class="updated">
        Updated: 23/10/2024
       </div>

.footer .uk-container {
	max-width: 1300px;
}


.footer p {
	color:white !important;
}
.footer a {
	text-decoration: underline;
}
.wpcf7-form {
	text-align: left;
	padding: 20px 0;
}


.wpcf7-text, .wpcf7-textarea, .wpcf7-submit {
	padding: 15px;
	border: 1px solid #E8E8E8;
	width: 90%;
}

.wpcf7-submit {
	background-color: #f7f7f7;
	border: 2px solid #e75d1f;
	color: #e75d1f;
	text-transform: uppercase;
	padding: 15px;
	transition: 0.2s ease;
	width: 40%;
	float: center;
	
}

.wpcf7-submit:hover {
	background-color: #e75d1f;
	color: #fff;
	transition: 0.2s ease;
	cursor: pointer;
}

#map {height:650px; width:100%; margin:0; padding:0;}

   <main class="tm-main uk-section uk-section-default" id="tm-main" uk-height-viewport="expand: true">
    <div class="uk-container">
     <article class="uk-article post-354 page type-page status-publish hentry" id="post-354" typeof="Article" vocab="https://schema.org/">
      <meta content="Internships/Research Stay" property="name"/>
      <meta content="Lenka Volenikova" property="author" typeof="Person"/>
      <meta content="2024-10-23T09:13:26+00:00" property="dateModified"/>
      <meta class="uk-margin-remove-adjacent" content="2019-10-19T09:10:23+00:00" property="datePublished"/>
      <h1 class="uk-article-title">
       Internships/Research Stay
      </h1>
      <div class="uk-margin-medium" property="text">
       <p>
        <span style="font-weight: 400;">
         GLODEP’s priority is to increase the employability and competitiveness of the program’s graduates. The emphasis is on direct contact between the students and potential employers. Therefore the internship/research stay is an integral part of the program curriculum, which enables students to receive hands-on experience related to the degree and their future careers. Research stays are generally carried out at Consortium Universities and
        </span>
        <a href="https://glodep.eu/consortium/academic-associates/">
         <span style="font-weight: 400;">
          Academic Associates.
         </span>
        </a>
        <span style="font-weight: 400;">
         Internships are mainly organized in cooperation with
        </span>
        <a href="https://glodep.eu/consortium/non-academic-associates/">
         <span style="font-weight: 400;">
          Non-Academic Associates.
         </span>
        </a>
       </p>
       <p>
        <span style="font-weight: 400;">
         The internship/research stay is prepared in cooperation with the tutor from the receiving institution and the coordinator from the supervisor’s university in charge of the internship/research. Students choose the institution of their internship/research stay and their supervisor and submit the thesis assignment by the end of November of the second academic year. The duration of the internship/research stay is 3–4 months.
        </span>
       </p>
       <h4>
        <span style="color: #333333;">
         SPECIFIC EXPERIENCE OF OUR STUDENTS
        </span>
       </h4>

       <script>
        (function($){

    // get the images of the gallery and replace it by a canvas of the same size to fix the problem with overlapping images on load.
    $('img[width][height]:not(.wk-overlay-panel)', $('#wk-grid48b')).each(function() {

        var $img = $(this);

        if (this.width == 'auto' || this.height == 'auto' || !$img.is(':visible')) {
            return;
        }

        var $canvas = $('<canvas class="wk-responsive-width"></canvas>').attr({width:$img.attr('width'), height:$img.attr('height')}),
            img = new Image,
            release = function() {
                $canvas.remove();
                $img.css('display', '');
                release = function(){};
            };

        $img.css('display', 'none').after($canvas);

        $(img).on('load', function(){ release(); });
        setTimeout(function(){ release(); }, 1000);

        img.src = this.src;

    });

})(jQuery);

      </h1>
      <div class="uk-margin-medium" property="text">
       <h3>
        Course examination
       </h3>
       <p>
        <span style="font-weight: 400;">
         The course examination follows the rules of the Consortium university where the course is carried out. Each Consortium university awards marks based on its own grading system. The ‘local’ marks are converted to a common GLODEP grading system.
        </span>
       </p>

          <td style="width: 87.5122%;">
           <span style="font-weight: 400;">
            2
           </span>
          </td>
         </tr>
         <tr>
          <td style="width: 87.5122%;">
           <span style="font-weight: 400;">
            1
           </span>
          </td>
         </tr>
         <tr>
          <td style="width: 87.5122%;">
           <span style="font-weight: 400;">
            0
           </span>
          </td>
         </tr>
        </tbody>
       </table>
       <h3>
        Master Thesis
       </h3>
       <p>
        <span style="font-weight: 400;">
         The topic of the master thesis is linked to the internship/research stay. By the end of November of the second academic year and after consultation with the supervisor(s) the students submit the topic of their thesis. The formal assignment shall be submitted into the Palacky University system STAG by January. A thesis can only be supervised by academic staff, but students may consult other specialists.
        </span>
       </p>
       <h3>
        State Final Examination
       </h3>
       <p>
        <span style="font-weight: 400;">
         The Final Examination takes place at Palacky University Olomouc at the end of the 4th semester, at the end of June. It is composed of an oral exam and a defense of the master thesis.
        </span>
        <span style="font-weight: 400;">
         Students are examined by a Committee composed of the academic members of the three Consortium Institutions. The three topics of the oral exam  include:
        </span>
       </p>
       <ol>
        <li aria-level="1" style="font-weight: 400;">
         <span style="font-weight: 400;">
          Sustainable Development and Foresight
         </span>
        </li>
        <li aria-level="1" style="font-weight: 400;">
         <span style="font-weight: 400;">
          Development Studies
         </span>
        </li>
        <li aria-level="1" style="font-weight: 400;">
         <span style="font-weight: 400;">
          Economics of Sustainable Development
         </span>
        </li>
       </ol>
       <div class="updated">
        <span style="color: #000000;">
         Updated: 24.10.2024
        </span>
       </div>
      </div>
     </article>
    </div>

.footer .uk-container {
	max-width: 1300px;
}


.footer p {
	color:white !important;
}
.footer a {
	text-decoration: underline;
}
.wpcf7-form {
	text-align: left;
	padding: 20px 0;
}


.wpcf7-text, .wpcf7-textarea, .wpcf7-submit {
	padding: 15px;
	border: 1px solid #E8E8E8;
	width: 90%;
}

.wpcf7-submit {
	background-color: #f7f7f7;
	border: 2px solid #e75d1f;
	color: #e75d1f;
	text-transform: uppercase;
	padding: 15px;
	transition: 0.2s ease;
	width: 40%;
	float: center;
	
}

.wpcf7-submit:hover {
	background-color: #e75d1f;
	color: #fff;
	transition: 0.2s ease;
	cursor: pointer;
}

   <main class="tm-main uk-section uk-section-default" id="tm-main" uk-height-viewport="expand: true">
    <div class="uk-container">
     <article class="uk-article post-358 page type-page status-publish hentry" id="post-358" typeof="Article" vocab="https://schema.org/">
      <meta content="Diploma" property="name"/>
      <meta content="Lenka Volenikova" property="author" typeof="Person"/>
      <meta content="2024-10-23T07:43:53+00:00" property="dateModified"/>
      <meta class="uk-margin-remove-adjacent" content="2019-10-19T09:11:24+00:00" property="datePublished"/>
      <h1 class="uk-article-title">
       Diploma
      </h1>
      <div class="uk-margin-medium" property="text">
       <p>
        <span style="font-weight: 400;">
         Successful students will be awarded a joint Master Diploma by all three Consortium Institutions:
        </span>
       </p>
       <ul>
        <li aria-level="2" style="font-weight: 400;">
         <span style="font-weight: 400;">
          Magistr (Mgr.) v magisterském studijním programu Global Development Policy  [
         </span>
         <i>
          <span style="font-weight: 400;">
           Master in master program Global Development Policy]
          </span>
         </i>
         <span style="font-weight: 400;">
          from Palacký University Olomouc
         </span>
        </li>
        <li aria-level="2" style="font-weight: 400;">
         <span style="font-weight: 400;">
          Master of Science (M.Sc.) in
         </span>
         <i>
          <span style="font-weight: 400;">
           Development Economics
          </span>
         </i>
         <span style="font-weight: 400;">
          from the Georg-August-Universität Göttingen
         </span>
        </li>
        <li aria-level="2" style="font-weight: 400;">
         <span style="font-weight: 400;">
          Master mention Economie du Développement, parcours Development Economics
         </span>
         <i>
          <span style="font-weight: 400;">
           [Master program in Economics of Development, specialization Development Economics]
          </span>
         </i>
         <span style="font-weight: 400;">
          from University of Clermont Auvergne
         </span>
        </li>
       </ul>
       <p>
        <span style="font-weight: 400;">
         Students also receive a
        </span>
        <a href="http://www.upol.cz/en/skupiny/students/degree-students/diploma-recognition/#c1705">
         <span style="font-weight: 400;">
          Diploma Supplement
         </span>
        </a>
        <span style="font-weight: 400;">
         issued by Palacky University, which contains marks from all semesters converted to a common GLODEP grading system. The diploma Supplement is issued a few days after the Final Exam. A Joint Master Diploma is distributed to the students in several months after the Final Exam.
        </span>
       </p>
       <p>
        <span style="font-weight: 400;">
         GLODEP – Palacky University (as the leading Consortium university)
        </span>
        <b>
         does NOT provide GPA scores
        </b>
        <span style="font-weight: 400;">
         . The diploma supplement includes all marks converted to a common GLODEP grading system (A-F, according to UPOL, Czech Republic). GLODEP grading only distinguishes between two categories of students –
        </span>
        <b>
         graduated and graduated with honors –
        </b>
        <span style="font-weight: 400;">
         as stated in the Diploma Supplement.
        </span>
       </p>
       <ul>
        <li aria-level="1" style="font-weight: 400;">
         <span style="font-weight: 400;">
          Graduated with honours – (i)
         </span>
         <a href="https://glodep.eu/new/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/code.jpg">
          <span style="font-weight: 400;">
           “weighted average”
          </span>
         </a>
         <span style="font-weight: 400;">
          from the courses not more than 1,5 and (ii) state exam and defence – average not more than 1,25 (both conditions have to be met)
         </span>
        </li>
        <li aria-level="1" style="font-weight: 400;">
         <span style="font-weight: 400;">
          Graduated – if not fulfilled conditions above
         </span>
        </li>
       </ul>
       <p>
        <span style="font-weight: 400;">
         Upon request, the Study department of the Faculty of Science (UPOL) can provide the students with weighted averages for courses (excluding state exam and thesis defense).
        </span>
       </p>
       <div class="updated">
        Updated: 23.10.2024
       </div>
      </div>
     </article>
    </div>

	padding: 20px 0;
}

	padding: 15px;
	border: 1px solid #E8E8E8;
	width: 90%;
}

.wpcf7-submit {
	background-color: #f7f7f7;
	border: 2px solid #e75d1f;
	color: #e75d1f;
	text-transform: uppercase;
	padding: 15px;
	transition: 0.2s ease;
	width: 40%;
	float: center;
	
}

.wpcf7-submit:hover {
	background-color: #e75d1f;
	color: #fff;
	transition: 0.2s ease;
	cursor: pointer;
}

   <main class="tm-main uk-section uk-section-default" id="tm-main" uk-height-viewport="expand: true">
    <div class="uk-container">
     <article class="uk-article post-360 page type-page status-publish hentry" id="post-360" typeof="Article" vocab="https://schema.org/">
      <meta content="Board of Directors" property="name"/>
      <meta content="Lenka Volenikova" property="author" typeof="Person"/>
      <meta content="2024-10-31T09:57:48+00:00" property="dateModified"/>
      <meta class="uk-margin-remove-adjacent" content="2019-10-19T09:11:52+00:00" property="datePublished"/>
      <h1 class="uk-article-title">
       Board of Directors
      </h1>
      <div class="uk-margin-medium" property="text">
       <p>
        The Board of Directors determines the main direction of the program operation and development.
       </p>
       <h3>
        Consortium Director
       </h3>
       <h4>
        <img alt="" class="alignleft wp-image-730" decoding="async" sizes="(max-width: 290px) 100vw, 290px" src="https://glodep.eu/new/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/Simona-Safarikova-290x300.jpg" srcset="https://glodep.eu/2024/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/Simona-Safarikova-290x300.jpg 290w, https://glodep.eu/2024/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/Simona-Safarikova-768x796.jpg 768w, https://glodep.eu/2024/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/Simona-Safarikova-988x1024.jpg 988w, https://glodep.eu/2024/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/Simona-Safarikova.jpg 1737w" width="170">
         Simona Šafaříková (Palacký University Olomouc)
        </img>
       </h4>
       <p>
        <a href="http://studydevelopment.cz/about/staff/safarikova/">
         Simona Šafaříková
        </a>
        <span style="font-weight: 400;">
         focuses on development opportunities in different regions of Asia. She also teaches qualitative research methods and is involved in global education. She joined the Department of Development & Environmental Studies in 2008. In the first semester of GLODEP at Palacky University she is involved in the teaching of Development Geography and Research Methods in Development. Her research interests are the role of sport in development and the impact of physical activities on solutions to development problems. Simona has published several academic articles in the field of sport and development. She has experience from several research and teaching stays abroad (e.g. Mexico, Colombia, South Africa, Mongolia, France).
        </span>
       </p>
       <p>
       </p>
       <h3>
        Local Directors
       </h3>
       <h4>
        <img alt="" class="wp-image-1376 alignleft" decoding="async" height="205" sizes="(max-width: 157px) 100vw, 157px" src="https://glodep.eu/2024/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/lenka-230x300.png" srcset="https://glodep.eu/2024/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/lenka-230x300.png 230w, https://glodep.eu/2024/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/lenka.png 583w" width="157">
         Lenka Dušková (Palacký University Olomouc)
        </img>
       </h4>
       <p>
        <span lang="en-GB">
         <a href="http://studydevelopment.cz/about/staff/duskova/">
          Lenka Dušková
         </a>
        </span>
        <span style="font-weight: 400;">
         has been working at the Department of Development and Environmental Studies since 2007. She focuses on issues of “
        </span>
        <i>
         <span style="font-weight: 400;">
          conflict sensitive development
         </span>
        </i>
        <span style="font-weight: 400;">
         ” and the use of mediation and facilitation techniques in project management in transforming and/or post-conflict regions. She is a lecturer of courses: Security, Conflict and Development; Politico-geographical Processes in Developing World (good-governance), Qualitative Research Methods and Development Theories. Recently, she has done research on impacts of civil society organizations in Bosnia and Herzegovina; community development in Central and Eastern Europe and Balkans, socio-ecological systems  and knowledge for development systems in Zambia. Besides academia, she is engaged in conflict transformation training and consultancy and community mapping including the development of participatory tools.  In her work she emphasizes active participation and use of dialogue.
        </span>
       </p>
       <p>
       </p>
       <h4>
        <img alt="pascale-combes-motel" class="wp-image-1436 alignleft" decoding="async" height="191" src="https://glodep.eu/wp-content/uploads/pascale-combes-motel.jpg" width="158"/>
        Pascale Combes Motel (University Clermont Auvergne)
       </h4>
       <p>
        <a href="http://has been a full Professor of Economics at the School of Economics, Université Clermont Auvergne, since 1999. She obtained a degree in agricultural engineering in 1988 and her PhD in economics in 1992. Before being appointed Associate Professor at the University of Caen Basse Normandie in 1993, she was a post-doctoral researcher in the Department of Economics at Université Laval (Québec, Canada). Pascale Combes Motel supervises two tracks of the Master's degree taught at the School of Economics: the "Développement durable" track (Sustainable development) with Professor Sonia Schwartz and the English-taught track "Development Economics" with Professor J-L. Combes. She is the local director of the Erasmus Mundus Joint Master's Degree GLODEP (Global Development Policy), which welcomed its first cohort of students in 2018.She teaches in French and English from Bachelor to Master's level: macroeconomics, macro-dynamics, optimisation for economists, environmental and natural resource economics, and the economics of sustainable development. Pascale Combes Motel is affiliated with the LEO (Laboratoire d’Economie d’Orléans – Orléans Economics Laboratory). Her research interests relate to the economics of sustainable development, mining activities, tropical deforestation, conflicts and natural resources, energy transition, and protected areas. She has published in the Journal of African Economics, Revue Economique, Economic Modelling, Environment and Development Economics, Energy Economics, World Development, Journal of Environmental Economics and Management, Economic Modelling, and Ecological Economics. She currently supervises 6 PhD students. She is an associate editor for the Journal of Forest Economics and International Economics. CV - Available at: https://cv.hal.science/pascale-combes-motel">
         Pascale Combes Motel
        </a>
        <span style="font-weight: 400;">
         has been a full Professor of Economics at the School of Economics, Université Clermont Auvergne, since 1999. She obtained a degree in agricultural engineering in 1988 and her PhD in economics in 1992. Before being appointed Associate Professor at the University of Caen Basse Normandie in 1993, she was a post-doctoral researcher in the Department of Economics at Université Laval (Québec, Canada).
        </span>
       </p>
       <p>
        <span style="font-weight: 400;">
         Pascale Combes Motel supervises two tracks of the Master’s degree taught at the School of Economics: the “Développement durable” track (Sustainable development) with Professor Sonia Schwartz and the English-taught track “Development Economics” with Professor J-L. Combes. She is the local director of the Erasmus Mundus Joint Master’s Degree GLODEP (Global Development Policy), which welcomed its first cohort of students in 2018. She teaches in French and English from Bachelor to Master’s level: macroeconomics, macro-dynamics, optimisation for economists, environmental and natural resource economics, and the economics of sustainable development.
        </span>
       </p>
       <p>
        <span style="font-weight: 400;">
         Pascale Combes Motel is affiliated with the
        </span>
        <a href="https://www.leo-univ-orleans.fr/">
         <span style="font-weight: 400;">
          LEO
         </span>
        </a>
        <span style="font-weight: 400;">
         (Laboratoire d’Economie d’Orléans – Orléans Economics Laboratory). Her research interests relate to the economics of sustainable development, mining activities, tropical deforestation, conflicts and natural resources, energy transition, and protected areas. She has published in the Journal of African Economics, Revue Economique, Economic Modelling, Environment and Development Economics, Energy Economics, World Development, Journal of Environmental Economics and Management, Economic Modelling, and Ecological Economics. She currently supervises 6 PhD students. She is an associate editor for the Journal of Forest Economics and International Economics.
        </span>
       </p>
       <p>
        <span style="font-weight: 400;">
         CV – Available at:
        </span>
        <a href="https://cv.hal.science/pascale-combes-motel">
         <span style="font-weight: 400;">
          https://cv.hal.science/pascale-combes-motel
         </span>
        </a>
       </p>
       <p>
       </p>
       <h4>
        <strong>
         <img alt="" class="wp-image-1375 alignleft" decoding="async" height="192" sizes="(max-width: 152px) 100vw, 152px" src="https://glodep.eu/2024/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/vollmer-238x300.jpg" srcset="https://glodep.eu/2024/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/vollmer-238x300.jpg 238w, https://glodep.eu/2024/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/vollmer-812x1024.jpg 812w, https://glodep.eu/2024/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/vollmer-768x968.jpg 768w, https://glodep.eu/2024/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/vollmer-1219x1536.jpg 1219w, https://glodep.eu/2024/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/vollmer.jpg 1428w" width="152"/>
        </strong>
        Sebastian Vollmer (University of Göttingen)
       </h4>
       <p>
        <span style="font-weight: 400;">
         <a href="https://www.uni-goettingen.de/en/prof-dr-sebastian-vollmer/450695.html">
          Sebastian Vollmer
         </a>
        </span>
        <span style="font-weight: 400;">
         is Professor of Development Economics at the University of Göttingen. His research examines the economic and social causes and consequences of bad health, access to care for cardio-metabolic diseases in the global south, the impact of nutrition interventions on child development and the long-run determinants of economic development. Sebastian Vollmer studied Mathematics and Economics at the University of Göttingen and also received his PhD in Economics from the University of Göttingen. He was Postdoctoral Research Fellow at Harvard University, Visiting Assistant Professor of Economics at Dartmouth College and Adjunct Professor of Global Health at the Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health. He regularly works as a consultant for international organizations such as the World Bank, UNICEF, UNDP, UNESCO, WFP, FAO and several other organizations. He has published more than 150 articles in peer-reviewed journals (including Quarterly Journal of Economics, The Lancet and Nature). Professor Vollmer has received the KfW Development Bank Prize for Excellence in Applied Development Research and the Science Award of the German Society of Health Economics. He has supervised 15 PhD theses as first supervisor and more than 30 as second or third supervisor or external committee member.
        </span>
       </p>
       <div>
       </div>
       <div class="updated">
        <em>
         Updated: 23.10.2024
        </em>
       </div>
      </div>

     <article class="uk-article post-366 page type-page status-publish hentry" id="post-366" typeof="Article" vocab="https://schema.org/">
      <meta content="Consortium Universities" property="name"/>
      <meta content="Lenka Volenikova" property="author" typeof="Person"/>
      <meta content="2024-11-21T12:03:35+00:00" property="dateModified"/>
      <meta class="uk-margin-remove-adjacent" content="2019-10-19T09:13:16+00:00" property="datePublished"/>
      <h1 class="uk-article-title">
       Consortium Universities
      </h1>
      <div class="uk-margin-medium" property="text">
       <h3>
        <a href="http://www.upol.cz/en/">
         Palacký University Olomouc
        </a>
        , Czech Republic
       </h3>
       <p>
        Palacky University in Olomouc, the Coordinating Institution, is the second oldest university in the Czech Republic (founded in 1573) and educates almost 22 000 students at 8 faculties. The
        <a href="http://studydevelopment.cz/">
         Department of Development & Environmental Studies
        </a>
        (located in the
        <a href="http://www.prf.upol.cz/en/">
         Faculty of Science
        </a>
        ) is involved in the GLODEP master and offers the International Development Studies program at bachelor, master and doctoral level. Thus is the flagship university of development studies in Central and Eastern Europe. All programs are taught in Czech and the master program is also taught in English. The department is very active in international cooperation (e.g. student and staff exchanges with about 25 universities within the Erasmus+ program).
       </p>
       <p>
        <iframe allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen" data-mce-fragment="1" frameborder="0" height="281" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/z1nHw2xhw3M?feature=oembed" width="500">
        </iframe>
       </p>
       <p>
        <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pFEkqBibUPQ">
         Olomouc Honest Guide
        </a>
       </p>
       <p>
        <a href="https://www.upol.cz/welcome-office/">
         Welcome Office at Palacký University Olomouc
        </a>
       </p>
       <p>
        <a href="https://skm.upol.cz/en/">
         Dormitory at Palacký University Olomouc
        </a>
       </p>
       <p>
       </p>
       <h3>
        <a href="http://www.clermont-universite.fr/">
         University of Clermont Auvergne
        </a>
        , France
       </h3>
       <p>
        <span style="font-weight: 400;">
         The University Clermont Auvergne was founded on January 1, 2017, with the merger of the two universities of Clermont-Ferrand, both created in the 16
         <sup>
          th
         </sup>
         century. With 36 000 students, among whom 6000 are of foreign nationalities, and 900 are PhD students, around 1300 researchers and professors-researchers, and 35 research centers, this new dynamic, attractive, and responsible university is open to its social, economic and cultural surroundings on its territories and on the world. The School of Economics, which is involved in the GLODEP program, designed a strategy for international development and is offering a master’s program in Development Economics, which is taught in French and English. The research center
        </span>
        <a href="http://cerdi.org/">
         <span style="font-weight: 400;">
          CERDI
         </span>
        </a>
        <span style="font-weight: 400;">
         (Centre for Studies and Research on International Development) is affiliated with the
        </span>
        <a href="http://www.cnrs.fr/index.php">
         <span style="font-weight: 400;">
          CNRS
         </span>
        </a>
        <span style="font-weight: 400;">
         (National Centre for Scientific Research). This affiliation is a recognition of research excellence.
        </span>
       </p>
       <p>
        <span style="font-weight: 400;">
         Since obtaining the I-SITE label in 2017, the University of Clermont Auvergne has joined forces with other institutions linked to higher education and research in the region to unite around a common ambition: the creation of a university of teaching and research with a national and international dimension, strongly connected to its territorial environment and its region. Against this backdrop, the new Université Clermont Auvergne – Établissement Public Expérimental (EPE) came into being on 1 January 2021.
        </span>
       </p>
       <p>
        <iframe allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture; web-share" allowfullscreen="" frameborder="0" height="281" referrerpolicy="strict-origin-when-cross-origin" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/dCq2rqNsCkU?feature=oembed" title="Découvrez l'Université Clermont Auvergne" width="500">
        </iframe>
       </p>
       <p>
       </p>
       <h3>
        <a href="https://www.uni-goettingen.de/en/1.html">
         <b>
          University of Göttingen
         </b>
         <span style="font-weight: 400;">
          ,
         </span>
        </a>
        <b>
         Germany
        </b>
       </h3>
       <div>
        <span style="font-weight: 400;">
         The University of Göttingen – founded in 1737 in the Age of Enlightenment, the University of Göttingen is committed to the values of social responsibility of science, democracy, tolerance, and justice 13 faculties offer a comprehensive range of subjects in the natural sciences, humanities, social sciences, and medicine. 535 professors and over 4,000 scientific staff at the University of Göttingen are committed to meeting the highest standards of quality in research and teaching. Students can choose their subject of study from more than 200-degree programs.
        </span>
        <span style="font-weight: 400;">
         <br/>
        </span>
        <span style="font-weight: 400;">
         The University of Göttingen is an internationally renowned research university: Around 4,500 students from 138 countries, 510 exchange partnership programs with 90 countries, membership in European and international higher education networks, a wide range of funding opportunities for internationally mobile students and researchers, and more than fifty English-language Master’s and Ph.D. programs – these are just a few features of Göttingen University’s strong international orientation.
        </span>
       </div>
       <div>
       </div>
       <div>
       </div>
       <div>
        <a href="https://goettingen-campus.de/">
         The
         <span style="font-weight: 400;">
          Göttingen
         </span>
         Campus
        </a>
       </div>
       <p>
       </p>
       <p>
       </p>
       <p>
       </p>
       <p>
       </p>
       <div class="updated">
        Updated: 23.10.2024
       </div>
      </div>
     </article>

.footer .uk-container {
	max-width: 1300px;
}

	color:white !important;
}

	text-decoration: underline;

	text-align: left;
	padding: 20px 0;
}


.wpcf7-text, .wpcf7-textarea, .wpcf7-submit {
	padding: 15px;
	border: 1px solid #E8E8E8;
	width: 90%;
}

.wpcf7-submit {
	background-color: #f7f7f7;
	border: 2px solid #e75d1f;
	color: #e75d1f;
	text-transform: uppercase;
	padding: 15px;
	transition: 0.2s ease;
	width: 40%;
	float: center;
	
}

.wpcf7-submit:hover {
	background-color: #e75d1f;
	color: #fff;
	transition: 0.2s ease;
	cursor: pointer;
}
